ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would definitely recommend this class to any student interested in the history of the 19th and 20th century US, even if s/he were not particularly interested in "culture" to begin with.
AMST 731 is a excellent introduction to the cultural history approach in American studies. I would recommend it highly to those interested in American history.

I would recommend this course to cultural historians and all history and American studies students who are interested in considering how to write about culture, a notoriously nebulous object of study.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Even though I was one of the few non-historians, it was really useful for me to get a better understanding of the field of cultural history, and to think about how it compares and is different from cultural sociology. I come away with authors I want to read further, and methods of analysis I can use in the future. The syllabus final assignment looking at the culture of nonviolent social movements may very well end up as a dissertation topic. Thank you!!!
Yes. The course opened up the field of cultural history and will have a positive impact on my work in religious history.

This course was very helpful in considering cultural studies/history as a discipline and in thinking methodologically. It pushed me to consider new ways of thinking about my research. I do wish, however, that we had spent a little more time in class talking about methodology as such.
